text: australia is ending its long-standing
arrangement that seen asylum seekers
attempting to get into the country sent
to a processing center in papua new
guinea rights groups in the u.n have
previously criticized australia's
hardline process accusing it of housing
asylum seekers in sub-standard
conditions offshore where many people
suffered abuse from sydney sham khalil
explained the next steps
the two countries have decided that
starting january 2022 papua new guinea
png will be fully responsible for the
regional processing services of the
remaining asylum seeker
in
in the country they will offer them
citizenship they will offer them
permanent package settlement packages
and family reunification if those
remaining asylum seekers do not wish to
remain in png the uh they will either be
sent to narrow island which is the other
place um australia detains people who
are trying to reach it by vote or they
could be resettled in a third country it
basically means that australia and png
are no longer um in a deal
for australia to send those asylum
seekers to the country this is of course
part of the um very controversial stop
the boats policy that started in 2013
a very hard-line policy which meant that
anyone fleeing trying to get to
australia by boat were sent
to a detention center uh on png's manus
island it was criticized by human rights
activists by the u.n by the united
states um for it is for its harsh
conditions and also uh for the mental
health effects that it's had on uh on
people now this detention center on man
on manus island has been closed down and
almost emptied really of the many people
that were there all of them almost all
of them have gone about 124
asylum seekers um remain and these are
the ones that are now going to be
processed uh by png nauru island um that
still remains um another place but all
in all i think it's the beginning of a
change if you will
and australia
the australian government giving up one
of those regional processing at center
in this really controversial uh policy
let's take you live now to hobart in
tasmania in australia i'm joined by nick
mckim australian green senator and the
party spokesperson on issues of
immigration nick i know you've been to
these detention centers in papua new
guinea you've seen what happens there
you must then welcome this decision
today
well we do welcome and it is a small
step in the right direction but remember
as your intro correctly pointed out that
there are two countries that australia
has engaged to um in regards to offshore
detention and offshore processing and
the uh system and the frameworks on
nauru still remain so uh we we welcome a
small step forward we'd like to see it
go further but there are still many
hundreds of people caught up in what is
a brutal and inhumane system so nick is
there a long-term plan then for the
government to wind down nauru
well no they've unfortunately
just re-extended some of the contracts
they have with private sector companies
on nauru so it doesn't look as if they
will
end offshore detention anytime soon
which is you know a tragedy for the
people involved obviously but also for
australia's international reputation and
also for other countries around the
world including the uk who seem to be
copying our policies of
brutality and inhumanity nick what did
you see when you went to papua new
guinea what sort of treatment did these
people suffer
look they were kept in conditions that
were completely unacceptable remember
these are innocent people they committed
no crime and their only mistake really
was reaching out a hand to australia and
asking for assistance and for protection
and for asylum and
for that um they were exiled forcibly um
to either nauru in the case of women and
children and family groups or to manas
island in the case of single men and
they were detained there in horrendous
conditions for
up to eight years now and on one of my
trips i witnessed a situation where the
australian and papua new guinean
governments colluded to cut off the food
the drinking water the electricity and
the medical support from about 650
people in the lombram prison and they
those conditions where they were
basically digging water are digging
holes to try and find fresh water to
drink the p g police were going into
that center and overturning the rubbish
bins that they'd collected rain water in
um you know it just beggars belief the
brutality and the the inhumanity of that
system there are many in australia who
do support it though nikki including the
government is there evidence to prove
that the treatment of these people did
act as a deterrent to others
well interestingly the government will
claim that it stopped the boats but
that's just a big fat political lie
really it didn't stop the boats there
are still people who are desperate
enough to
to entertain a dangerous sea voyage and
we are still turning boats back at sea
as recently as this year and of course
what it's done is it's changed the mode
of arrival and people are now in record
numbers arriving by plane to seek asylum
in australia so it's a policy failure
but it's come at the expense of this
this brutal dehumanizing
regime but it's also poisoned our
politics in australia and massively
damaged what previously was a very good
international reputation for human
rights mckim thank you for joining us
from hobart
